content:
Hai. You're pretty much there.
All that is to be changed is the key should be `"metadata.source"` and use `MatchText` to look for the substring as `MatchValue` is for keyword values, numbers, bool.
```python
client.scroll(
    qdrant_collection_name,
    scroll_filter=models.Filter(
        must=[
            models.FieldCondition(
                key="metadata.source", match=models.MatchText(text="MSM")
            )
        ]
    ),
)
```
You can use `delete()` to remove points by specifying this filter.
You can refer to the full-text match guide here.

content:
Yes, this is indeed a limitation of the Kubernetes StatefulSet controller.

One way to do this as mentioned in the StackOverflow article:

* Delete the StatefulSet while keeping the Pods running
```
kubectl delete statefulset --cascade=orphan qdrant
```
* Edit the PVC size to the desired larger size, e.g. to 20Gi
```
kubectl edit pvc qdrant-storage-qdrant-0
```
* Reinstall the Helm chart with the recreate-pods Flag. This will restart the Pods and during restart the PVCs will be expanded
```
helm upgrade --install qdrant qdrant/qdrant --set persistence.size=20Gi --recreate-pods
```

Note that your StorageClass must allow volume expansion.

Thanks. It seems like `qdrant-java-client` doesn't support the simple lookup using only vectors, and they require using named vectors (the 2nd example).
I think what happens with your request is that our HTTP framework fails to parse the request (cause `name` field is required, but missing) and returns overly generic error.

Here's the REST API doc, you can see there are two examples for the `vector` parameter: it's either an array (for single vector collection) or an object `{ "vector": [0.1, 0.2, 0.3], "name": "vector-name" }`.

https://qdrant.github.io/qdrant/redoc/index.html#tag/points/operation/search_points
Or you can create a collection to have multiple "named" vectors. And from your snippet, I think you are configuring your client to send _named_ vector search request.

In Qdrant you can create collection to either have a single, "default" vector, in which case search request body should look like the second example you've sent:
`POST /collections/my_collection/points/search -d '{"vector":[0.1,0.2,0.3]}'`

> or something similar

Hi @bigbluechief. `qdrant-java-client` is not maintained by Qdrant, so I'm not familiar with it, __but__ from the snippet you've sent, I think it should just be `PointSearchRequest().setVector(vectors)` or something similar.

It sends this request, which responds with a 422 Unprocessable Entity:

According to Qdrant's documentation, the request should be

so, is the Java SDK implemented wrongfully, or what am I doing wrong?

If you've replicated your data across multiple nodes, it'll allow continuous read and writes to the cluster as another replica will still be available.

Note that if you don't have replicated data, taking one node down will take the cluster down.
Imagine you have a cluster with 10 machines. In that case you'd upgrade each node separately, so that only one node is down at any given time.
However, the recommended way of updating a cluster is to do it per node.

content: Any latency changes during this process are likley unnoticable. The system was designed that way. So it'll probably be fine to leave the defaults.

Searching 'immutable segments' will use the index. Searching 'mutable segments' will do a full scan (or brute force search). Note that that should still be very fast as these segments will contain minimal data.

If you insert data, data is added to a 'mutable segment'. That segment does not have an index and allows adding points.

If that 'mutable segment' has enough points (and reaches the indexing threshold) it is turned into an 'immutable segment' by the optimizer. Then it is optimized, and an index is created for it.

To clarify, this happens for bigger chunks, not for individual points.

> When a new vector and payload is added  the index will be rebuilt.  By default will this cause any latency or outage issues on the production reads?
No outage, but higher latency is possible but probably barely measurable.

Yes. If you memory map your vectors, the quantized vectors will be memory mapped as well.

You could set `always_ram` to `true` to disable this behavior and always keep in RAM.

In your case, you could leave it at the default of `false` or define it explicitly.

You can read more about this parameter here: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/quantization/#setting-up-scalar-quantization

**config/prod.yaml**
```
log_level: INFO

storage:

service:

  max_workers: 0

  enable_cors: true
  enable_tls: false

```

**Context**: I have the below config for qdrant, but requests last too much in distinct instance types.

Below are two scenarios, both with the following collection and its config:

```
{"status":"green","optimizer_status":"ok","vectors_count":8112979,"indexed_vectors_count":8111922,"points_count":7978822,"segments_count":13,"config":{"params":{"vectors":{"image":{"size":2048,"distance":"Cosine"}},"shard_number":1,"replication_factor":1,"write_consistency_factor":1,"on_disk_payload":true},"hnsw_config":{"m":16,"ef_construct":100,"full_scan_threshold":10000,"max_indexing_threads":0,"on_disk":true},"optimizer_config":{"deleted_threshold":0.2,"vacuum_min_vector_number":1000,"default_segment_number":0,"max_segment_size":null,"memmap_threshold":10000,"indexing_threshold":20000,"flush_interval_sec":5,"max_optimization_threads":1},"wal_config":{"wal_capacity_mb":32,"wal_segments_ahead":0},"quantization_config":null},"payload_schema":{"property_type":{"data_type":"keyword","points":7978822},"sepomex_id":{"data_type":"keyword","points":7978822},"ad_id":{"data_type":"keyword","points":7978822}}}

**Scenarios**

*aws ec2 c6a.8xlarge*: 7 aws batch jobs where send simultaneously with average response times for search + scroll of X embeddings with an average response of 0.14 seconds. In this case, our resources where boost up to 100% vCPUs usage and memory stayed below 7%. 32 vCPUs and 64GB of RAM.

*aws ec2 c6a.2xlarge*: 2 aws batch jobs are being sent simultaneously, however, the CPU usage does not goes upper than 2% in average and memory usage stays equivallently in 28%. This instance has 8 vCPUs and 16GB in memory. Sadly, the average response goes up to 20 seconds.

Hi @kacperlukawski  
I'll just give a brief overview of the usecase:
We plan to run a cron job every 24hrs to insert new points from database to our vectorDB via a async workflow. 
So in case we observe any application layer failures in the workflow, retreiving the latest inserted id would be benifical for us to start from that point.

```python

#%%
from qdrant_client import QdrantClient
from sentence_transformers import SentenceTransformer

class NeuralSearcher:

    def __init__(self, collection_name):
        self.collection_name = collection_name
        # Initialize encoder model
        self.model = SentenceTransformer('all-MiniLM-L6-v2')
        # Initialize Qdrant client
        self.qdrant_client = QdrantClient(
            url="https://a280s-east4-0.gcp.cloud.qdrant.io:6333", 
            api_key="d_77oAA2iw")

    def search(self, text: str):
        # Convert text query into vector
        print("Converting text to vector")
        vector = self.model.encode(text).tolist()
        print("Vector created")

        # Use `vector` for search for closest vectors in the collection
        print("Initiating vector search")
        try:
            search_result = self.qdrant_client.search(
                collection_name=self.collection_name,
                query_vector=vector,
                query_filter=None,  # No filters for now
                limit=5  # Limiting to 5 closest results
            )
            print("Vector search completed successfully")

            # Process search results
            payloads = [hit.payload for hit in search_result]
            if payloads:
                print(f"Found {len(payloads)} results")
            else:
                print("No results found")

            return payloads

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error during vector search: {str(e)}")
            raise e

#%%


```

```
client.search(

where our query_filter_conditions are set in this way:
```
query_filter_conditions = [
    FieldCondition(key='timestamp', range=Range(gt=None, gte=timestamp_lb, lt=None, lte=None))
]
if metadata is not None:
    for k, v in metadata.items():
        query_filter_conditions.append(FieldCondition(key=k, match=MatchValue(value=v)))
```
so, for example, it might look something like
```
query_filter_conditions = [
    FieldCondition(key='timestamp', range=Range(gt=None, gte=12345, lt=None, lte=None)),
    FieldCondition(key='guild_id', match=MatchValue(value=12345)
]
```
both are integer indexes - guild_id is technically discrete, but i found integer index to be much faster in practice (on 1.4.1 at least).

Hello! First of all, thanks for building a great product! I've been very impressed with performance and ease of use.

I'm playing around with self-hosted Qdrant in a k8s cluster (16 replicas, handling ~250 reads & writes per second), and just went ahead with an upgrade from 1.4.1 -> 1.6.1, but noticed pretty a considerable increase in search latency (round trip), P50 latency from ~6ms -> 27ms.

I also noticed the memory utilization dropped quite a bit while CPU utilization increased considerably.

I've attached some metrics we're sending to datadog so you can see how the upgrade affected our instance.

We also upgraded the helm chart version from 0.2.8 -> 0.6.1, but are still using Python client version 1.1.7 for requests.

I'd love to understand:
1. Why memory utilization dropped & CPU increased because of the upgrade (was payload pushed entirely to PVs?)
2. What might've changed in this upgrade that could cause this latency increase - do we need to upgrade our Python client version or change how we're querying the database?

One other potential relevant piece of information is that we're running several collections that use payload indexing on the same cluster (for isolation and simplicity). I know this isn't recommended, but it seemed to work fine with version 1.4.1 - did something change about how things works?

https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant/blob/master/tools/generate_docker_compose_cluster.sh

You could use the following to generate and start a Docker compose file for 3 nodes:
```
./generate_docker_compose_cluster.sh 3 > docker-compose.yaml
docker-compose up
```

content:
A Qdrant instance (with `cluster: true` enabled) binds three ports.

- 6333 (HTTP API)
- 6334 (gRPC API)
- 6335 (internal cluster communication)

If you want to start a second instance on the same machine, you'd have to define different ports for your second instance.

You could run two instances with the following two commands:

```
# First instance
QDRANT__CLUSTER__ENABLED=true qdrant --uri http://localhost:6335

# Second instance
QDRANT__CLUSTER__ENABLED=true QDRANT__SERVICE__HTTP_PORT=6343 QDRANT__SERVICE__GRPC_PORT=6344 QDRANT__CLUSTER__P2P__PORT=6345 QDRANT__STORAGE__STORAGE_PATH=./storage2 qdrant --bootstrap http://localhost:6335
```

Thats the part i'm trying to figure out. I see two options.

One is to run sub queries on each of the returned results. For example:
1. Thumbs up on product #1
2. Return results from recommend groups API
3. Take each of the returned image vectors and query qdrant again for exact matches or ones above a 99% score.
4. Run them in parallel or batch api for speed and combine/group accordingly.

Option two is to do a quick HNSW on the returned image vectors. This route is quicker because you are only comparing against the limit of the returned recommend groups API. The downside is it wont capture all the matched vectors where the images are the same so there is lots of hidden records.
